snippet: The remarkably healthy teeth of prehistoric humans in Africa have high levels of compounds found in purple nutsedge, which may have helped ward off cavities.
abstract: Dr Stephen Buckley study in journal PLoS One suggests that ancient humans may have reaped dental benefits from eating cyperus rotundus, invasive weed commonly known as purple nutsedge.
lead_paragraph: The remarkably healthy teeth of prehistoric humans in Africa have high levels of compounds found in purple nutsedge, which may have helped ward off cavities.

headline.main: Now a Weed, Once a Prehistoric Cavity Fighter
headline.print_headline: Archaeology: Now a Weed, Once a Prehistoric Cavity Fighter
